Q2 (a) Identify any three of the following continental beef cattle.
A: Charolais
B: Aubrac
3+2+1
C: Limousine
D: Simmental
E: Belgian Blue
(b) Outline a reason why farmers put a ring in a bull’s nose.
Safety / control bull / easier to handle / legal requirement (after 4
10 months)

Q3 (a) Outline three management practices carried out by the students from
calves arriving on the farm to weaning.
Isolate calves from others for a few days / feed glucose or
electrolyte solution / feed milk or milk replacer (once or twice a
day) / good feed equipment hygiene (milk troughs or buckets or
3+3+2
milk trolley) / feed at the same regular intervals each day /
clean dry bed / adequate space / draft free or well ventilated /
vaccination (IBR or pneumonia or scour) / disbudding / penned
according to age / access to water / introduce hay / introduce
concentrates
(b) Identify the weaning weight of a dairy beef calf at weaning.
130kg
2
90kg 
75kg
12

Q4 Outline one reason why each of the following farming practices is
carried out.
Controlled grazing: increased yield of crop / effective harvesting of
crop or increased forage intake / increased biodiversity /
decrease fossil fuel usage or reduced labour and feed costs /
increased digestibility of the sward / fewer weeds /
environmentally responsible grazing areas
Crop rotation: helps return nutrients to the soil or better nutrient
management / reduced need for artificial fertilisers / interrupt
6+2+2
pest or disease cycles or weed cycles / improve soil health or
improves soil structure or decreases compaction / increasing
biomass from different crops root structures / increase
biodiversity on the farm.
Using organic fertilisers: reduced need for artificial fertilisers or
cheaper or more sustainable / improve water movement into
the soil / add structure to the soil / feed beneficial microbes /
increase soil fertility / meet organic certification or customer
preference

Q5 Using your knowledge of biosecurity, explain how each of the following
can threaten the biosecurity on a farm and outline what the farmer
can do to reduce the risk in any two.
Threaten Biosecurity Reduce Risk
Can pass the disease Isolate new animals
(infect) onto other when entering the farm
4+4+1+1
Sick animals animals or humans / / isolate sick animals /
cause a disease vaccination / cull sick
outbreak on the farm animals
Contaminated Can carry disease Wash or disinfect
vehicles and between farms (on vehicles and equipment
equipment tyres) / in slurry tankers between farms

Q6 (a)(i) State your understanding of BCS.
Body condition score / technique used to assess how fat or thin 6
an animal is / score 1 – 5 (1 = very thin and 5 = very fat)
(ii) Identify the best quality silage and state which animals this silage is
suitable.
Best quality silage = 76%+ DMD or A 2
Suitable animals = freshly calved dairy cows in winter milk 1
(iii) State which silage DMD % is suitable for dry suckler cows that have a
good BCS.
<67(%) or D 1
13
Or
(b) Outline the process a farmer would carry out to get good quality
silage.
Spread fertiliser or slurry 6 weeks before cutting / test grass for
during or after rainfall / cut using a precision chop mower / cut
6+2+2
around middle of May or when grass is in vegetative stage / leave in
rows (swathes) / allow to wilt for 24 hours / bale or bring to pit /
shake out with a pitchfork to remove large clumps / roll tightly to
remove air / use an additive (acid or molasses) / cover with plastic /
weigh down with tyres / allow time for fermentation to occur

Wiping the teat with antiseptic wipe / wash the parlour or milk lines

2(4)
milking machine regularly / clip tails / (selective) dry cow therapy /

Abomasum* 3

no regurgitation of food

Fertility check or check for abnormalities in the scrotum or

no sudden changes in diet / observe bull is serving the cows /

season / avoid stress

Bull 4

Bull 1

Fast results so can treat the disease or pest quickly / know if

Q13 (a)(i) Outline reasons why reseeding is recommended.
Increased productivity or excess silage (can be sold) or
increased liveweight gain or increased milk yield or increased
4+2
better nitrogen use efficiency or reduced nitrogen requirement
/ longer growing season or extended grazing / better silage or
grass quality / increased protein or mineral content / less
disease or weeds / reduce soil compaction
(ii) Identify the plants that may be sown in a newly reseeded pasture.
A: Red clover
B: Perennial ryegrass 6+3+3
C: White clover
(clover accepted once only)
(iii) Outline reasons for sowing plants A and C shown in part (ii) in a newly
sown sward.
Increased grass quality or production / increased dry matter
increased mineral content / nitrogen fixation or less artificial
fertilizer / reduce weeds / increase biodiversity
(b)(i) Identify which reseeding method(s) have the highest potential for
grass production.
Disc 6
(ii) Outline what conclusion the researchers can make in relation to the
sustainable reseeding methods.
There is very little difference in the grass growth (between all
the reseeding methods) or sustainable methods as good as 2
plough or it would be better for the environment to use the
sustainable methods / correct ranking in relation to
sustainability (using data from graph)
(iii) Briefly describe the advantages of reseeding using the one pass system.
Cheaper than the conventional ploughing method / less soil
disturbance or no need to plough or less compaction / fewer 4+2
stones / suitable for shallow soils / conserves soil moisture /
conserves soil biodiversity / land fallow for shorter period
17
(c)(i) Outline key points a farmer needs to consider when deciding what
grass mixtures to sow.
Intended use of grass / varieties suitable to farm / animal
4+2
production type / soil type / introduction of clover / multi
species swards / palatability / productivity or yield / heading
date
(ii) Advise the farmer as to where to access information on grass varieties.
Department of Agriculture / recommended varieties list / 6
Teagasc / (local) seed companies / other valid example
OR
(d) Describe how a farmer would manage a newly reseeded sward in its
first year after sowing.
Good weed control (selective herbicide) / ready for grazing
(roots don’t pull up when grazed) / fertilise / light stock to
2(6)
prevent poaching / increase tillering (fertiliser or grazing or
topping) / pest control

Q14 (a)(i) Explain disease resistance and time of harvest (in named food crop
bar grass).
Disease resistance: Ability to prevent or reduce the presence of 2
diseases in a crop / or correct example
Time of harvest: The time of the year during which the crop is 2
harvested / or correct example
(ii) State one essential element required by the crop and describe its role.
Element: N, P K, S etc.
2
Role: N for protein formation or increases yield or chlorophyll
formation or component of amino acids or DNA or ATP or ADP
/ P for growth or energy or ATP or ADP or root growth or seed
(fruit) formation or tillering / K for growth or yield or
development or resist drought or disease resistance or helps 2
plants use water or translocation of carbohydrates / or any
valid example with a matching valid role
(iii) Briefly outline two factors which affect the preservation of the crop.
Factors: Temperature or light / pH / oxygen / moisture
Outline of factor:
Temperature – if temperature is too warm crop can overheat
or respire causing spoiling of the crop or if temperatures are Factors-
too cold frost damage can occur or light will cause potatoes to 2(2)
sprout or turn green
pH – if pH is not suitable grain may sprout in storage or grain
may rot Outline-
2(1)
Oxygen – foods store best with no oxygen or the presence of
oxygen may speed up spoilage
Moisture – crops last longer when moisture is removed (e.g.
reducing moisture in cereal crops)
18
(iv) Describe the safety considerations Lisa should consider when
harvesting the crop.
Be careful of moving machinery or keep children away from
yard / PTO covered / wear gloves or a mask / turn off
machinery if clearing any blockages / extreme care on steep 2(4)
slopes / maintain a safe distance from waterways /
experienced operators on machinery or machinery in proper
working order / safety signs or cones on entrances or exits to
roads
reason for your .
Diagram: C 4
Reason: Different crops sown / lots of trees / animals are not
4
allowed into river to drink / flowers or trees present or
boundary created to allow for natural growth / no spraying
(ii) Outline the reason for the crop X being sown between the cows and
the river in diagram A.
Wildlife corridor / prevent soil erosion into river / prevents the 4
cattle from drinking in or entering the river / reduce nutrients
leaching into the river / increase biodiversity
(iii) Outline the advantage of spot spraying compared to spraying the
whole field.
Less chemicals required or reduce pollution or more
environmentally friendly / only treat the target plant /
reduced resistance to herbicide / reduced cost of expensive
chemicals
(iv) State which diagram represents farming in the least environmentally
friendly way and give two reasons for your .
Diagram: B
Two reasons: cattle drinking in river / splash plate slurry
spreading or slurry being spread near the river / no trees or
2(4)
plants / monoculture / no wildlife corridors / river banks are
being eroded into the river / water quality (eutrophication) /
spraying weed killer (near river)

Q15 (a)(i) Describe how he took soil samples for analysis.
Random / min 20 samples / 10 cm in depth / soil corer or
sampler or auger / divide land into areas of 2-4 hectares /
account for differences in soil type or slope or previous
2(5)
cropping history / W shape / avoid gateways or troughs or
beside ditches or wet land / store samples from the same field
together
(marks can be awarded for points on diagram)
(ii) Identify which soil is compacted and give a reason for your .
Soil sample – B 5
Reason – less (air) spaces or soil particles closer together 5
(iii) Outline the effects of soil compaction on a farm.
Reduced crop yield or delayed germination or poor
establishment or shorter growing season / reduced water
availability or water intake / reduced root development
(penetration) or mineral uptake / reduced animal production
4+2
(reduced milk yield or lower LWG) / increased surface run-off or
pollution / reduced water infiltration or poor drainage or
flooding / reduced gaseous exchange which stunts plant growth
/ soil erosion / formation of plough pan / reduced optimal living
conditions for soil organisms
(iv) Suggest ways farmers can reduce soil compaction on their farm.
(Mole) plough or subsoil / reseed / multi species swards or
reduce tillage / reduce stocking density / construct drainage or
lime regularly / house animals in prolonged wet weather /
increase organic matter / reduce traffic or axle loads (animal or
machinery) / (add diversity to) crop rotations
(v) Describe with the aid of a labelled diagram how he carried out this
investigation to compare capillarity.
Two open ended tubes / put cotton wool in one end / dry soil /
fill (same amount of soil tubes) with soil A and other with soil B
/ place tubes in beakers of water / leave for a period of time / 3(2)
measure the height of the water column in each / description of
water movement or valid result
(Points can be found on the diagram)
(vi) State two errors that could have occurred in the investigation in part (v).
Different amounts of soil or time or water or soil type / failure
to tap the glass to remove large soil spaces / soil not fully dry /
2(1)
another valid example
(b) Label diagram.
A: Top Soil
6+4
B: Sub soil
20
Or
(c) Complete the graph to show the average organic matter and water
composition of a brown earth soil.
Organic matter – 5%
6+4
Water – 25%

Q16 (a)(i) Describe with the aid of a labelled diagram, how he would carry out the
investigation to check the quality of milk.
Place milk sample into test tubes / add few drops (1 cm3) of
Resazurin to three tubes (average) / place in water bath / at 37oC /
for 15 minutes / record colour change
Result: (allow one only)
Fresh – blue – good quality (low TBC)
Blue – deep mauve = good
(Deep) pink = fair
(Light) pink = poor
White = poor
Total Bacterial Count on the Sample:
Get a sample of milk and carry out a serial dilution of the milk
sample by adding 1ml of milk into 9ml of distilled water & shake to
mix / take 1ml from this test tube and add to 9ml of distilled water
& shake / repeat this for 4 more test tubes / take 1ml of milk from 3(4)
the last test tube & place on a prepared nutrient agar plate under
aseptic conditions. Repeat 3 times for accurate results / spread the
milk around the plate using a plate spreader / leave one agar plate
unopened as a control / place in incubator for 72 hours at 25oC /
remove plate & record number of bacteria colonies on the plate &
multiply by 106 to get the number of CFU’s / ml of milk /
Result: There will be CFU’s in the plate over - time as the number
of bacteria in the sample multiply causing a decrease in quality of
the milk.
There are other valid tests a student could do - % protein / %
butterfat (gerber method) / Presence of Thermoduric bacteria
(serial dilution) / presence of antibiotics (Devlo test) / SCC –
California Mastitis Test (CMT) / % Solids in a milk sample (excess
water)
(Points can be found on the diagram)
(ii) Identify the following variables in the investigation in part (i).
Independent Milk sample
Quality – colour change of resazurin / cfu in
Dependent
bacterial count
3(2)
Fresh milk sample or milk sample of known
quality or equal volumes of milk or equal
Control
volumes of Resazurin or all test tubes sterile or
any other valid control variable
21
(iii) State with reason if the data collected is qualitative or quantitative.
Data
Resazurin test – qualitative TBC - quantitative
type 2+2
Resazurin – colour change as TBC – count number of
Reason
result / non-numerical data CFU’s / numerical data
(b)(i) Outline ways Pat could reduce the number of bacteria entering the milk.
Teat dipping pre and post milking / milk socks or filtering / (hot)
wash machine regularly / change liners regularly (twice per year)
6+6
/ lime on cubicles / clean housing or clean lying area / clip hair on
cow’s tails / wash and dry udder / control flies or mastitis /
operator hygiene
(ii) Calculate the price Pat gets for 1000 litres of his milk in the table
below if the milk fat is 3.8% and protein is 3.4%.
€174.72 + €317.45 – €40 3
= €452.17 3
(If a candidate gives 452.17 without showing any calculation they
may be awarded 6m)
(c)(i) Explain climate-neutral dairy farm.
The amount of greenhouse gas emissions a farm produces is
balanced by absorbing or removing equivalent emissions in the 2
atmosphere or the carbon used = the carbon saved or a
balanced carbon footprint / or valid explanation
(ii) Outline why each of the following ingredients are added to the diet of
a dairy cow.
4
Beans: source of protein / increase in milk fat
Barley: source of carbohydrate or energy 4
22

Q17 (a)(i) Briefly describe the advantages of ultrasound scanning.
Determine number of lamb’s ewe is carrying / identify barren
ewes / estimate lambing date / group and feed ewes to ensure
4+2
body condition and lamb birth weight or more economical or
efficient use of feed / reduce problems at lambing or reduce
twin lamb disease / ease of fostering
(ii) Explain the importance of having a good marking system for the ewes
at scanning.
Know how many lambs’ ewes are carrying / identify barren 4
ewes to cull / for management of ewes prior to lambing or at
housing / ease of fostering
(iii) Outline the advice you would give on the management of the ewes based
on the results.
Cull the ewes that are not in lamb / adequate number of pens or
pen the ewes according to the number of lambs / fosters from 4+2
triplets / increase or improve the quality of concentrate feeding
for multiple births (prevent twin lamb disease) or restrict feed
intake for singles / plan for adequate supervision during lambing
(b)(i) Advise the farmer as when to house the ewes prior to lambing.
4 – 8 weeks prior to lambing / start of steaming up / correct
4
time of year indicted (Jan/Feb)
(ii) Suggest reasons for housing the ewes prior to lambing.
Allow for early grass / protect sheep (from cold conditions during
lambing) / easier feeding or management / reduce mortality at
lambing / less predators / reduce stress on pregnant ewes
(iii) List features of winter housing for sheep.
Adequate feeding space (450 mm) or all sheep can feed from
the one feeding passage / adequate lying space (1.2 m²) or
adequate pen depth (2.7m) / good ventilation / draft free /
individual lambing pens / group pens / clean bedding or slats /
water troughs
(c) Describe the management practices carried out on lambs in the first
week after birth.
Feeding – colostrum for antibodies or to warm up or laxative or 6
energy / milk or milk replacer
Housing – individual pen or fostering crate to bond with mother
/ group pen for hardening off / turned out with mother/ clean 6
dry bedding
Health – iodine on navel to prevent joint or navel ill / vaccination
(e.g. Orf) / tag for identification / tail dock / castration male
6
animals / place under infra-red to prevent chill or give glucose
injection / any other valid disease prevention or treatment in
first week
23

Q18 (a)(i) Identify the function of the underlined term by
6
placing a tick ( ) in the correct box. Genetic information 
(ii) Explain how the police used the DNA evidence to prove that the heifer was stolen.
Blood samples were taken from cow / (DNA) matched other cows
2(6)
from original farm

Sexed semen- semen is separated into X and Y chromosomes and
farmer can choose if they want a heifer or bull / genomic selection –
genetically estimating the breeding value of animals / or other valid
innovation method of farming
(b)(i) Explain how the gene editing process works.
Gene responsible for a specific trait is identified / CRISPR-Cas9 edits
3+1
genes by precisely cutting DNA at the target gene / desired gene is
inserted / natural DNA repair processes occurs
(ii) Briefly describe the advantages of gene editing.
Breed high yielding plants or superior animals or increase growth in
food production and quality / disease resistant plants or animals /
pest resilient crops / results quicker than selective breeding / can
target specific diseases / good precision with ability to target
individual cell types / drought resilient crops / genetically polled
breeds / or any two valid examples
(iii) Explain any two of the following ethical or economic issues of producing GM
crops in Ireland.
Impact on environment: GM crops can help reduce agricultural
greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions / less fertiliser requirements / fewer
chemical sprays required / negative – herbicide resistant weeds
Effect on food chain: More nutritious food / tastier food / disease
4+2
resistant or pest resistant plants or drought resistant / less use of
chemicals / increased supply of food with reduced cost / longer shelf
life of food / negative - allergies
Increase in production: increased yield of plants / less weeds / less
diseases / faster growing / negative – market place monopoly / lower
the value of crops
(c)(i) Explain selective breeding.
Selective breeding involves choosing parents with particular
2+2
characteristics to breed together / produce offspring with more
desirable characteristics.
(ii) Briefly explain two characteristics farmers or scientists would select in their
breeding programme.
(High) crop yields / resistance to disease / (high) growth rate / (good) 6+2
conformation / good milk production (yield and milk solids) /
prolificacy / or any two valid examples
